questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right foot pain for 3 months. She has a burning sensation in the plantar area between the third and fourth metatarsals that radiates to the third and fourth digits. She is an account executive and wears high heels to work every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right lower extremity shows intact skin. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. When pressure is applied to the sole of the foot between the metatarsal heads the patient feels pain and there is an audible click. Tapping on the affected area causes pain that shoots into the third and fourth digits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A first metatarsophalangeal joint sprain, also called turf toe, manifests with swelling, tenderness, and an inability to move the first toe. This patient has none of these features and instead has pain on palpation of the third intermetatarsal space.

B) INCORRECT:

Third metatarsal stress fractures commonly occur in individuals who regularly run or have a high-intensity exercise program like military personnel. Even though this patient has pain on palpation of the third intermetatarsal space, she does not have a classical history associated with a stress fracture. Additionally, stress fractures do not manifest with neuropathic pain (i.e., radiating burning pain) and a positive Tinel sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Metatarsal osteochondrosis, also called Freiberg disease, affects the second metatarsal and is typically seen in adolescent girls. However, this patient's symptoms are limited to the third metatarsal space and the adjoining toes. Additionally, metatarsal osteochondrosis manifests with pain and swelling over the metatarsal and is not associated with the neuropathic pain seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Intermetatarsal neuroma (also called Morton neuroma) is caused by entrapment or enlargement of one of the plantar digital nerves, in this patient likely the medial plantar nerve, and typically manifests with neuropathic pain in the plantar aspect of the foot that is exacerbated by palpation. The condition is commonly seen in individuals who wear narrow or high-heeled footwear and is characterized by the presence of Mulder sign and Tinel sign.

Morton neuroma is a clinical diagnosis based on history and provocation testing. If there is clinical uncertainty, imaging is appropriate to confirm the diagnosis or exclude alternative causes of chronic foot pain. Initial treatment includes reducing pressure on the metatarsal heads through wide footwear and orthotics. Other treatment options include ultrasound-guided corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections. Surgical resection of the neuroma may be necessary for symptomatic individuals who do not respond to other therapy modalities.

E) INCORRECT:

A ganglion cyst may cause pain in the foot, but would most likely occur with movement and not be associated with burning sensation, an audible click, or a positive Tinel sign. Additionally, most ganglion cysts are palpable as small bumps and are typically located in the posterior wrist.

F) INCORRECT:

Although osteomyelitis can also cause foot tenderness, this patient does not have fever, fatigue, or any localized signs of osteomyelitis like a draining sinus tract. There is also no history of any risk factors for osteomyelitis like an open wound or immunosuppression. Additionally, osteomyelitis does not manifest with neuropathic pain and a positive Tinel and Mulder sign.
questions.hint: The medial plantar nerve is likely involved in the disease process affecting this patient.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of an inward turning of his left forefoot. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation by cesarean section because of breech presentation. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Examination shows concavity of the medial border of the left foot with a skin crease just below the ball of the great toe. The lateral border of the left foot is convex. The heel is in neutral position. Tickling the lateral border of the foot leads to correction of the deformity. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the left foot shows an increased angle between the 1st and 2nd metatarsal bones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot abduction brace is used to prevent relapses in cases of idiopathic clubfoot deformity (congenital talipes equinovarus; CTEV) after complete correction but is not indicated for uncomplicated metatarsus adductus unless other treatment options have failed. CTEV can be differentiated from metatarsus adductus deformity based on the alignment of the hindfoot, which would be in inverted and elevated position for patients with CTEV but is neutrally positioned in this child.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteotomy is used to correct metatarsus adductus deformities that do not correct spontaneously within 5 years of age and where all other interventions have failed. In this newborn with flexible metatarsus adductus who has not yet undergone any form of treatment, surgical correction would be not be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthrodesis is indicated for the correction of forefoot deformities that do not respond to conservative treatment. It is rarely a first-line treatment option in children, as their bones are still growing and the anatomical orientation of the bones can be expected to still change. A surgical fusion of the foot bones at this stage would lead to relapse or further deformity as the bones continue to grow.

D) CORRECT:

This child has a flexible and uncomplicated metatarsus adductus (as evidenced by a lack of pain or other abnormalities and the deformity correcting itself on tickling the lateral border). Since this is a benign congenital deformity that resolves spontaneously in > 95% of cases within the first 18 months of life, reassurance is the most appropriate next step in management.

In contrast to flexible metatarsus adductus, rigid metatarsus adductus or metatarsus adductus with associated pain/limb length discrepancy/persistence beyond 5 years of age requires further management (e.g., serial casting, surgical correction).
Image Description:

Left: feet of a neonate; Right: x-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view) of the same patient

Bilateral forefoot adduction is seen on the photograph. The radiograph shows medial deviation of each of the five metatarsals at the tarsometatarsal joints.

E) INCORRECT:

Repositioning with serial casting is used to manage cases of clubfoot (congenital talipes equinovarus; CTEV) and rigid/persistent metatarsus adductus. A metatarsus adductus deformity can be differentiated from CTEV based on the alignment of the hindfoot, which would be inverted and elevated for patients with CTEV but is neutrally positioned in this child. A rigid metatarsus adductus can be ruled out because a rigid deformity would be corrected neither actively (on tickling the lateral foot) nor passively (manual correction by the physician).

F) INCORRECT:

Tarsometatarsal capsulotomy is a corrective surgical procedure that is performed in cases of metatarsus adductus > 5 years of age that do not resolve spontaneously or show no response to serial casting. In this newborn with flexible metatarsus adductus who has not yet undergone any form of treatment, surgical correction would be counterindicated.

G) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is used as a treatment option in various conditions of foot deformity, like pes cavus, calcaneovalgus, or reducible clubfoot. Serial stretching exercises are indicated for cases of flexible metatarsus adductus in which only passive correction (manual correction by a doctor) to the midline is possible. Physical therapy is not indicated in this patient, in whom the flexible deformity can correct itself actively, on tickling the lateral side.
questions.hint: This newborn presents with in-toeing, a neutral hindfoot, and a c-shaped left forefoot with a medial skin crease. This presentation is consistent with flexible metatarsus adductus, the most common congenital foot deformity.

questions.text: A 4080-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows both feet pointing downwards and inwards. Both forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, with the hindfeet elevated and the midfeet appearing concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation. There are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity persists despite attempts to passively straighten the foot. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot abduction bracing prevents relapses after the initial correction of the club foot. At this point in the patient's presentation, however, another intervention aimed at correcting the deformity is first needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgery is not considered a first-line approach for the vast majority of club foot cases. Cases that require surgery are often those in which parents/caregivers have difficulty following the non-surgical treatment plan or those in which the deformity is so severe that conservative treatment is unlikely to alleviate the issues. In the event that other treatment options fail, surgery would be indicated to correct deformities in the tendons, ligaments, and joints of the foot and ankle.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is inappropriate in this patient because the deformity is rigid on examination, making the likelihood of spontaneous resolution very low. Club foot specifically is known to cause permanent deformity if not corrected in a timely manner.

D) CORRECT:

Repositioning and serial casting is the recommended treatment for patients with club foot. On clinical exam, the deformity cannot be passively corrected, indicating that intervention will be necessary to prevent future gait disorders. If repositioning and casting are initiated within 24 hours and continued through musculoskeletal development, the prognosis for this patient is excellent and surgery can likely be avoided.
Image Description:

Right lower leg and foot of a newborn, ventral view of the back of the foot

The achilles tendon is shortened, resulting in plantar flexion and the foot pointing downwards (hindfoot equinus). The calcaneus is supinated (hindfoot varus). The forefoot is adducted and supinated and rotates medially (forefoot varus). The midfoot cavus cannot be seen from this perspective.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy (PT) is an important element of caring for patients with club feet because it helps to provide optimal alignment, mobility, and range of motion. However, a primary correction of the deformity is required before PT can be initiated.
questions.hint: This newborn presents with in-toeing, an elevated hindfoot, and a cavus deformity of the midfoot bilaterally. This presentation is consistent with club foot, a common congenital foot deformity.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for evaluation prior to participation in sports. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. When the patient is standing, examination of the feet shows depressed medial longitudinal arches, heel eversion, and forefoot abduction bilaterally. The medial longitudinal arches are restored when the great toes are dorsiflexed, and when the patient is examined in the prone position. Strength is 5/5 in both lower extremities. Active and passive ranges of motion of the lower extremities are full. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Weight-bearing x-rays of the feet are indicated in patients with flexible flat feet who present with pain, decreased range of motion, or require preoperative evaluation. This patient is asymptomatic and has full active and passive ranges of motion in the lower extremities, so he does not require weight-bearing x-rays of the feet.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthotic insoles are not recommended for children with asymptomatic functional flat feet because there is insufficient evidence that this treatment improves clinical outcomes.

C) CORRECT:

Most cases of functional flat feet in children are physiologic and often resolve spontaneously during adolescence. Therefore, reassurance and expectant management are recommended for asymptomatic individuals. If the deformity is associated with pain and/or limited range of motion, further diagnostic (e.g., weight-bearing x-rays of the feet) and treatment are indicated. Conservative treatment of painful flat feet involves physical therapy and adequate shoe wear (e.g., orthotic use, supported heel counter). Flexible flat feet associated with limited ranges of motion can be caused by Achilles tendon contractures, which may require surgical treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Achilles tendon lengthening, which can be achieved by passive stretching or surgical reconstruction, is indicated in cases of flat feet that are associated with contractures of the triceps surae muscle that lead to limited ranges of motion. There is no evidence of muscle contractures in this patient, and the range of motion in his feet is normal, so a different step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with flat feet, an MRI of the spine is indicated when a spinal cause is suspected. Neural tube defects, such as meningomyelocele, can lead to neuromuscular dysfunction and subsequent foot deformities. This patient has no other symptoms of spinal cord dysfunction (e.g., motor or sensory defects, bladder or bowel dysfunction), so a spinal cause is unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's depressed medial longitudinal arches (MLA) with heel eversion and forefoot abduction are indicative of flat foot (pes planus). The restoration of the MLA in prone position and the full range of motion suggests a functional (flexible) flat foot, which is common in children and adolescents.

questions.text: You are caring for a male newborn, weighing 4080 g, delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. On examination in the delivery room, both feet are pointing downward and inward. The forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, the hindfeet are elevated, and the midfeet appear concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation, and there are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity does not resolve with passive manipulation. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Foot abduction bracing prevents relapses after the initial correction of the club foot. At this point in the patient's presentation, however, another intervention aimed at correcting the deformity is first needed.

B) CORRECT:

The Ponseti method, which consists of repositioning and serial casting, is the recommended treatment for patients with clubfoot. Casts are changed weekly, with most infants needing 57 casts over several weeks. An Achilles tenotomy is often performed before the final cast to correct any remaining equinus deformity. Once casting is complete, a foot abduction brace maintains correction. The brace is worn full time for 23 months, then during naps and at night until the age of 4 years. If repositioning and casting are initiated within the first week of life (to leverage the newborn's tissue flexibility) and continued through musculoskeletal development, the prognosis for this patient is excellent.

Key learning point: The initial management of club foot is prompt repositioning and serial casting to correct the deformity and prevent long-term disability.
